comments.body: Shouldn't we do it for other constants?

The only constant types supporting the alternative comparison with `eq` are classes and strings. Class literals are hash consed, so `==` and `eq` are the same. So I believe `String` is the only type in need of a fix.
To add, I didn't find this issue with integer constants.
`Null` might also take advantage of this unless some other optimization is already handling it.

comments.body: What about curried methods that have implicit parameters as the 3rd parameter clause? Should we accept them? I guess there's no problem with those since we would not have to resolve them right away, right? If yes, it would be good to state this here as an explanation.

There can be a problem... It looks like `applyOverloaded` resolves a method name looking only at the first argument group. E.g.:

```scala
def f(x: Int)(y: Int) given Z: Int
def f(x: String)(y: Int): Int
applyOverloaded("f", x: Any)
```

In both cases, the logic above infers `x.isImplicitMethod` to be `false`, so it cannot differentiate and can select the one with the implicit args at the end. Which it will never be able to call if we are after Typer.
Ah, OK. So we need to exclude all implicit methods, even of the implicit comes later.
@odersky do you think this is no longer a problem?
This line triggers the crash. I find it better to add `withSpan` for other constructors too.
Rename to `nestedPairsTypeTree`, since we already have a `nestedPairs` in TypeOps which denotes a type.
It seems type symbols should be skipped too? `isBinding` currently only ignores class symbols.
@liufengyun I added this other condition to fix a second bug with the same code
The guard is getting quite long. Maybe extract it into a `def` with a comment explaining when a symbol is skipped
It will be simpler to refactor this in the next PR I'm working on in which I already have to change the `skipLocal`
I think the idea of using an accumulator is good, but why the detour via lists? Let's use an accumulator over an immutable set instead.
You could try to do the same for TypeApply.
Yes, we could do that. I'm wondering how `if/else` could possibly appear in `fun`. But it is always good to have these invariants if they don't incur much performance cost.
You will probably not be able to. You could add the assertion to make sure.
Can we have nested `TypeApply`? Should we check `fn.isInstanceOf[Apply[_]]` instead of `fn.isInstanceOf[GenericApply[_]]`?
With named type arguments yes I think so `foo[A=Int][String]`
... also with curried type lambdas.
WIP further experiments suggest this can't be true, even tho this code works.
After normalization, we should not have them, so it should be fine or the normalization was not performed correctly.
True after normalization â€” I thought that was also true before normalization, but that was wrong.

comments.body: Missing documentation
Why is this needed ?

This is to prevent the qualifier of the `Select` nodes that we generate from being added to the results and avoid duplicates. The original qualifier (with the real position) will already be considered in `namedTrees` when we handle the `Import` nodes.

I added a comment in `def importSelections`.

It might be cleaner to just override the `transform` as follows:
```scala
override def transform(tree: Tree)(implicit ctx: Context): Tree = 
  if (tree.tpe.isError) tree else super.transform(tree)
```

I was debating what was simpler, and more efficient. I also first thought of overriding `transform`, but: (1) this requires a new `TreeMap` class in `tpd` (2) this adds a stackframe to each node traversal, which can add up. So I think the current approach is more lightweight in the end.
